case_name: Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd. v. D. R. Singh

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 423 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 423 of 1964.

facts.text: The appeal is by special leave from the order dated October 5, 1962 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal at Dhanbad.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated October 5, 1962 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal at Dhanbad in Applic

facts.text: The order relates to Application No. 53 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: in Application No. 53 of 1961 in Reference Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 196

facts.text: Industrial disputes pending under Reference Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Reference Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 196.1.

facts.text: Appellant is Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd., Jamadoba.

anchor.surface_text: the Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd.,  N 4SCI Jamadoba, filed an application under

facts.text: Appellant filed application under s. 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 before the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd.,  N 4SCI Jamadoba, filed an application under s. 33 2  b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

facts.text: Application sought approval for action proposed against employee, respondent D. R. Singh.

anchor.surface_text: , before the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad  hereinafter called the Tribunal , asking for its approval of the action which it proposed to take against its employee, the respondent D. R. Singh.

facts.text: Application filed because certain industrial disputes were pending between appellant and its employees under References Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: This application was made by the appellant, because certain industrial disputes were pending at the relevant time between the appellant and its employees under References Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961.

facts.text: Application opposed by respondent who filed written statement.

anchor.surface_text: This application was opposed by the respondent who filed his written statement.

facts.text: Appellant urged before Tribunal that application under s.33(2) was not necessary because respondent was not concerned with the pending industrial disputes.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the application, the appellant urged before the Tribunal that though it had made the present application as a matter of abundant caution, its case was that it was number necessary to apply under s. 32 2 , because the respondent was number companycerned with the industrial disputes

facts.text: One of the conditions precedent for s.33 is that the workman must be concerned in the main industrial disputes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that one of the companyditions precedent for the applicability of s. 33 is that the workman against whom the employer seeks to take action falling under s. 33 2 , must be a workman companycerned in the main industrial disputes

facts.text: Tribunal held appellant could not raise contention that s.33 did not apply and should withdraw application if so thought.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal took the view that the appellant companyld number raise such a companytention. It held that if the appellant thought that s. 33 did number apply, it should withdraw the application and take the companysequences.

facts.text: Tribunal refused to entertain plea and proceeded to deal with merits of application.

anchor.surface_text: On that view, it refused to entertain the plea raised by the appellant and proceeded to deal with the merits of the application.

facts.text: Tribunal not satisfied that prima facie case made out for dismissal of respondent, refused approval, dismissed application.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Tribunal was number satisfied that a prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent, and so, approval was number accorded to the action which the appellant wanted to take against the respondent and its application was accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave against Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Order terminating services of respondent passed on December 4, 1961 to take effect from December 9, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The order terminating the services of the respondent was passed on December 4, 1961 and it was to take effect from December 9, 1961.

facts.text: Tribunal's award pronounced on October 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Award was pronounced by the Tribunal on October 5, 1962,

facts.text: More than three years elapsed since date of dismissal of respondent by time of Supreme Court hearing.

anchor.surface_text: and when the appeal has companye for final disposal before us, more than three years have elapsed since the date of dismissal of the respondent.

facts.text: Solicitor-General for appellant conceded appeal not to enforce dismissal but for decision on point of law.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General fairly company- ceded that the appellant has companye to this Court number so much to enforce its order of dismissal against the respondent, as to have a

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal erred in not considering preliminary point on applicability of s.33.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General for the appellant companytends, and we think rightly, that the Tribunal was in error in number dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case.

facts.text: Supreme Court decided point of law in favour of appellant but dismissed appeal due to passage of time.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we have decided that point in favour of the appellant, but having regard to the long passage of time between the date of the impugned order and the date when we are pronouncing our judgment in the present appeal, we think it would be inexpedient and unjust to send the matter back to the Tribunal

facts.text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General and I. N. Shroff appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General and I. N. Shroff, for the appellant.

facts.text: Jitendra Sharma and Janardan Sharma appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Jitendra Sharma and Janardan Sharma, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Gajendragadkar, C. J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Gajendragadkar, C. J.
Appeal by special leave from the order dated October 5, 1962 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal at Dhanbad in Application No. 53 of 1961
under s. 33 2  b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  No. 14 of 1947   hereinafter called the Act , before the Central Government Industrial Tribunal

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal was in error in not dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General for the appellant contends, and we think rightly, that the Tribunal was in error in not dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case. It is plain that in a situation like the present, even if the appellant took the view that the workman against whom it was taking action was not a workman concerned with the main industrial disputes,

issues.text: Whether the respondent was a workman concerned in the relevant industrial disputes

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the application, the appellant urged before the Tribunal that though it had made the present application as a matter of abundant caution, its case was that it was not necessary to apply under s. 33 2 , because the respondent was not concerned with the industrial disputes which were pending between the appellant and its employees in the different References to which we have already referred. In other words, the appellant wanted the Tribunal to consider the question as to whether the respondent was a workman concerned in the relevant industrial disputes at all,

issues.text: Whether a prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Tribunal was not satisfied that a prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent, and so, approval was not accorded to the action which the appellant wanted to take against the respondent and its application was accordingly dismissed.

issues.text: What is the correct construction of the words 'a workman concerned in such dispute' in s. 33(1) and (2)

anchor.surface_text: The question about the construction of the words a workman concerned in such dispute which occur in s. 33 1  and  2  has been the subject matter of judicial decisions and somewhat inconsistent views had been taken by different High Courts on this point. Some High Courts construed the said words in a narrow way,

issues.text: What course should be adopted in dealing with the merits of the present appeal after holding that the Tribunal erred on the preliminary point

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the Tribunal was in error in not considering the preliminary point raised by the appellant that the respondent was not a workman concerned with the main industrial disputes and as such, the application made by it was unnecessary. That raises the question as to the course that we should adopt in dealing with the merits of the present appeal.

arguments.claim: It was not necessary to apply under s. 33(2) because the respondent was not concerned with the industrial disputes pending between the appellant and its employees

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the application, the appellant urged before the Tribunal that though it had made the present application as a matter of abundant caution, its case was that it was not necessary to apply under s. 33 2 , because the respondent was not concerned with the industrial disputes which were pending between the appellant and its employees in the different References to which we have already referred. In other words, the appellant wanted the Tribunal to consider the question as to whether the respondent was a workman concerned in the relevant industrial disputes at all,

arguments.court_reasoning: Wholly illogical and unsatisfactory; employer entitled to apply without prejudice amid conflicting precedents

arguments.claim: Tribunal was in error in not dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General for the appellant contends, and we think rightly, that the Tribunal was in error in not dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case. It is plain that in a situation like the present,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he appellant had numberdoubt made an application as a precautionary measure that is why it wanted the Tribunal to companysider its companytention that

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agreed and held tribunal erred

arguments.claim: Employer justified in making application under s.33 without prejudice to contention that s.33 did not apply, given risk of self-deciding amid conflicting views

anchor.surface_text: even if the appellant took the view that the workman against whom it was taking action was not a workman concerned with the main industrial disputes, it would be justified in refusing to take the risk of deciding the said point for itself. It would be legitimate for an employer like the appellant to make an application under s. 33 without prejudice to his case that s. 33 did not apply.

arguments.claim: Broader construction of 'workman concerned in such dispute' in s.33(1) and (2) is correct, as approved in binding precedents New India Motors and Digwadih Colliery

anchor.surface_text: The question about the construction of the words a workman concerned in such dispute which occur in s. 33 1 and 2 has been the subject matter of judicial decisions and somewhat inconsistent views had been taken by different High Courts on this point. Some High Courts construed the said words in a narrow way, vide New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd., Bhavnagar N. L. Vyas Ors., 1 while others put a broader construction on them, vide Eastern Plywood Manufacturing Company Ltd v. Eastern Plywood Manufacturing Workers Union 2 .

arguments.claim: Where judicial decisions conflict on construction, unreasonable to require employer to risk self-decision on s.33 applicability

anchor.surface_text: Where judicial decisions differed on the construction of the words workmen concerned in such dispute, it would be idle and unreasonable to suggest that the employer should make up his mind whether s. 33 applies or not, and, if he thinks that s. 33 does not apply, he need not make the application on the other hand, if he thinks that s. 33 applies,

arguments.claim: No prima facie case made out for dismissal of respondent

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Tribunal was not satisfied that a prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent, and so, approval was not accorded to the action which the appellant wanted to take against the respondent and its application was accordingly dismissed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Merits not examined due to time lapse

arguments.claim: Appeal not to enforce dismissal but to obtain decision on point of law

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General fairly conceded that the appellant has come to this Court not so much to enforce its order of dismissal against the respondent, as to have a decision from this Court on the point of law raised by it before the Tribunal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: se if the appellant is right in companytending that the respondent is number a workman companycerned with such disputes within the meaning of s. 32 2

arguments.court_reasoning: Decided point in favor but dismissed appeal due to delay

arguments.claim: Inexpedient and unjust to remand due to long passage of time since dismissal

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we have decided that point in favour of the appellant, but having regard to the long passage of time between the date of the impugned order and the date when we are pronouncing our judgment in the present appeal, we think it would be inexpedient and unjust to send the matter back to the Tribunal

holdings.text: The Tribunal was in error in not dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General for the appellant contends, and we think rightly, that the Tribunal was in error in not dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case. It is plain that in a situation like the present,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees with Solicitor-General that tribunal must address jurisdictional applicability of s.33 before merits; employer justified in cautious application

holdings.text: It would be legitimate for an employer like the appellant to make an application under s. 33 without prejudice to his case that s. 33 did not apply

anchor.surface_text: even if the appellant took the view that the workman against whom it was taking action was not a workman concerned with the main industrial disputes, it would be justified in refusing to take the risk of deciding the said point for itself. It would be legitimate for an employer like the appellant to make an application under s. 33 without prejudice to his case that s. 33 did not apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given risk of penalties for contravention, employer may apply under s.33(2)(b) as precaution despite believing non-applicability

holdings.text: The broader construction of the words 'a workman concerned in such dispute' which occur in s. 33(1) and (2) is correct as approved by this Court in Digwadih Colliery

anchor.surface_text: The question about the construction of the words a workman concerned in such dispute which occur in s. 33(1) and (2) has been the subject matter of judicial decisions and somewhat inconsistent views had been taken by different High Courts on this point. Some High Courts construed the said words in a narrow way... This problem was ultimately resolved by this Court... and has approved of the broader construction of the words workmen concerned in such dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Courts conflicted; Supreme Court in New India Motors and Digwadih Colliery resolved by preferring broader view over narrow

holdings.text: The Tribunal was in error in not considering the preliminary point raised by the appellant that the respondent was not a workman concerned with the main industrial disputes and as such, the application made by it was unnecessary

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the Tribunal was in error in not considering the preliminary point raised by the appellant that the respondent was not a workman concerned with the main industrial disputes and as such, the application made by it was unnecessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's refusal to entertain contention wholly illogical; must decide threshold applicability amid conflicting interpretations

holdings.text: Though the point on preliminary issue decided in favour of appellant, appeal dismissed without remand as inexpedient due to long passage of time

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we have decided that point in favour of the appellant, but having regard to the long passage of time between the date of the impugned order and the date when we are pronouncing our judgment in the present appeal, we think it would be inexpedient and unjust to send the matter back to the Tribunal... That is why though we have reversed the finding of the Tribunal on the preliminary point, we do not propose to give this litigation any further lease of life. In the result... the appeal fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.136 appeal seeks law point decision conceded by appellant; three years delay since dismissal makes remand unjust

anchor.surface_text: The question about the construction of the words a workman concerned in such dispute which occur in s. 33(1) and (2) has been the subject matter of judicial decisions and somewhat inconsistent views had been taken by different High Courts on this point. Some High Courts construed the said words in a narrow way... This problem was ultimately resolved by this Court... and has approved of the broader construction of the words workmen concerned in such dispute.
In the result, without examining the merits of the findings recorded by the Tribunal for number according approval to the dismissal of the respondent, we direct that the appeal fails and

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we have decided that point in favour of the appellant, but having regard to the long passage of time between the date of the impugned order and the date when we are pronouncing our judgment in the present appeal, we think it would be inexpedient and unjust to send the matter back to the Tribunal... That is why though we have reversed the finding of the Tribunal on the preliminary point, we do not propose to give this litigation any further lease of life. In the result... the appeal fails and is dismissed.
